column8: Independence Memorial Hall – Symbol of Freedom and Heritage
column11: The Independence Memorial Hall in Colombo is a remarkable landmark built in 1948 to honor Sri Lanka’s independence from British rule. Its stunning architecture, inspired by the ancient Audience Hall in Kandy, features elegant stone columns, lion statues, and intricate carvings that showcase the island’s heritage. Surrounded by peaceful gardens, it’s an ideal spot for a stroll, morning jog, or photography. Inside, a small museum provides deeper insight into Sri Lanka’s independence history, making this a must-visit cultural and historical site in Colombo.

column8: A symbol of the rebirth of the state.
column11: Independence Memorial Hall is located in Independence Square, Colombo, in Cinnamon Gardens.Built to commemorate the restoration of Sri Lanka's independence from British rule in 1948. The architecture of the hall is a see-through gallery with a roof covering 60 columns. Around are stone-eyed lions guarding the place of commemoration. Now there are annual religious events, celebrations of national holidays and wedding ceremonies. On the lawn street tamers offer to take a photo with a monkey or with snakes. A visit is mandatory.

Historical Independence Hall is a land mark of Colombo and it is located in an ancient styled hall overlooking a neat public garden opposite the independence hall. It stands proud in the middle of the city's upper class suburbs. This hall look like a concrete copy of the original Magul Maduwa called as the King’s Court in Kandy which is made out of wood. However the Independence hall is larger and more suitable to mark as the Independence monument from Britain. Sri Lanka culture is reflected in this memorial hall. It is a Long Hall with many concrete pillars and no walls except the roof. But the pillars and cross bars in the Kandy King’s Court is wooden and carved to make more beautiful and attractive. A beautiful monument which shows the culture and pride of Sri Lanka stands outside, replete with statue and flags, to mark Sri Lankan independence. The structure is huge with interesting moldings on its pillars and walls. At night, it looks even better with lighting. The hall itself is beautiful with high ceilings that provide surprising solution to the day's heat. It is cool inside the Independence Hall without A/C as the blowing continuously comes in. The murals on display are a treat to look at. Independence Arcade is located very close to the Independence hall. Sometimes the Independence Hall is used for certain important government functions. The present President, Hon Mitripala Sirisena gave his oaths at the independence hall when elected. The cremation funerals of renowned artists or Politicians,Renowned Buddhist Monks, Artists (Actors, Singers) are held here with nation’s respect. The Independence Memorial Hall in Colombo is a national monument of Sri Lanka built for the commemoration of the country's independence from British rule on 04 Feb 1948. This beautiful "hall" is set in Independence Square in the highly-upmarket area of Cinnamon Gardens and commemorates the granting if independence to the then Ceylon in 1948. Its design is based on that of the Royal Audience Hall of the Kingdom of Kandy where the Kandyan Convention (ending the independence of that kingdom) was signed with the British in 1815. A team of local and expatriate architects designed the building the construction of which began in 1949 and was completed in 1953. It was from a similarly-shaped hall that the Duke of Gloucester opened the first Parliament of independent Ceylon on 4 February 1948. In front of the Hall, and facing the newly-refurbished Arcade-Independence Square is the statue of the first Prime Minister and "Father of the Nation", Mr D S Senanayake. The surrounds are nothing less than serene: don't miss it!

This is a free attraction….open to the public and the elements!  But for his time of 15 minutes, we respectfully tipped him…..then he said it was 2,000 Rupees per person.  What 4,000 Rupees for a 15 minute chat?  When you pay less than that….he will barrage you with ‘did you not like my tour?, did it not make you happy?, you wouldn’t have known any of what this means, I am a teacher.’  He will say this as he shoulders alongside you as you try to get into the tuk tuk, in fact, the tuk tuk drivers stall thinking this will change your mind. This majestic stone edifice commemorates Sri Lanka gaining its independence from the British Empire in 1948. The exact location is where Prince Henry, the Duke of Gloucester, opened Sri Lanka’s first parliament on a special podium, bringing an end to almost five centuries of colonial rule and marking the beginning of Sri Lanka’s self-rule. Originally, the Independence Memorial Hall hosted important diplomatic guests and ceremonial assemblies of the two houses of the Parliament. In Order to appreciate this monument to freedom, one should make mental notes of the various symbolic references carved into the stone work.  Then go and research why certain symbols were used. But also spend some time in the nearby arcade. Arcade - Independence Square is located in Colombo 7 and is part of the process of beautifying Colombo. Well worth visiting this at the same time to get a nice cup of tea or a cool drink.  But also you can shop in some of the more trendy shops.  Try it!  You will not be disappointed.

The museum is organized very simply: begin your own tour from the left side (not like myself! ).It depicts in words and objects the full history ,in a very concise way, of Sri Lanka.I loved it. In the middle of the museum there are a few tens of statues of historical figures from the country's history. If you want to take pictures you have to pay extra.I don't know why but this museum is not mentioned in the guide book I bought(sorry I can not mention which one).I recommend this museum because of the easiness to understand in a simple way the history chart of the country.

I don't know why but in the guide book I bought about Sri Lanka this monument is mentioned in only 10 words.This is not fare.A little country like this fighting for independence after being occupied by Portuguise,Dutch and Brits really deserves such a monument.In my eyes the monument also known as Commemoration Hall is beautiful and imposing as such a monument should be. It is situated in the of Cinnamon gardens and very close to Viharamahadevi Park.If you walk from the North then you will use the Independence Avenue and shortly you will see the monument.Nicely ornated with stone sculptures and big stone columns the monument is elevated so it can be seen also from the street.Of course a huge flag stands in the front of it.More sculptures you can find also around the building - don't miss the lions ! After admiring the monument you can walk to the nearby Independence Arcade for refreshing and shopping. In the front of the museum facing the flag and at the park level there is the Independence Museum.Strongly recommended.
